awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  An AI-Based Collaborative Video Streaming Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve video streaming for applications ranging from consumer viewing to remote education. The proposed platform reduces the need for data centers and Content Distribution Networks (CDNs), leading to cost reductions for video delivery. By potentially reducing network congestion and increasing network resilience to failures, the resulting solution can help improve viewers’ experience.  Moreover, because video streaming represents 80+% of internet traffic, the proposed technology will contribute to a reduction in the energy consumption and carbon footprint of the cloud computing infrastructures currently used for this service. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project leverages and extend state-of-the-art research in artificial intelligence, stochastic systems and edge networks, addressing three key challenges: (1) Design of a decentralized artificial intelligence optimization algorithm that efficiently manages video traffic; (2) Design of an advanced simulation environment capable of efficiently mimicking the behavior of real-world networks of users for system design and assessment; (3) System optimization for use on a wide range of devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overwhelming transmissions of video contents over the Internet (accounting for 80+% of the total traffic) and high energy and costs of cloud and networking infrastructures for these transmissions call for investigations into more efficient solutions. In this Phase I SBIR project the feasibility of a collaborative Edge-Artificial Intelligence (Edge-AI) based solution (called AptStream) that can augment the current solutions and infrastructures to better leverage the available transmission links, storage units, and processing units in the network was extensively studied. The project was completed in three steps. First, a simulation environment for the training and evaluation of AptStream was developed. Second, using this environment, AI-based algorithms designed by the team for efficient transmissions were extensively studied and improved. Third, with the help of recent approaches, these algorithms were further optimized for on-device implementations. Optimized algorithms were then integrated with an augmented media player designed by the team leading to an initial prototype for AptStream. In typical scenarios for high-demand video-on-demand (VoD) contents studied in detail in this project, AptStream is expected to lead to approximately 2x to 4x cost reductions without tangibly affecting the Quality of Experience (QoE). If adopted widely, AptStream is expected to have several broader impacts by making video streaming more cost effective and efficient.

In order to develop and evaluate AptStream, a training/simulation environment that simulates the behaviors of VoD viewers and transient networks of viewers was developed. For this purpose, the company obtained and analyzed various datasets including a large dataset of VoD viewers over the span of several months. Furthermore, a study of the status of the internet connections in the country was conducted. In addition, for evaluation purposes, heuristic methods that leverage some aspects of the proposed method were also implemented as part of the simulation environments.

For efficient transmissions of video contents in viewers' networks, a Reinforcement Learning (RL)-based algorithm designed by the team was extensively studied and improved. The algorithm's main component is a lightweight Artificial Neural Network (ANN) implementable on a wide range of devices. Also, this novel RL-based solution was designed to be deployed in an almost completely decentralized manner. The main goal here was to reduce the number of transmissions from media servers which can consist of Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) -- smaller and more abundant nodes of the cloud computing infrastructures, the cloud computing servers, and/or on-premise data centers without tangibly affecting the QoE of the viewers (e.g., quality of the video playback). By reducing these transmissions, AptStream helps reduce the costs of content delivery for the users of the proposed solution.

In addition, to make the algorithm deployable on a larger set of devices, recent methods were used to reduce the size of the ANN model (i.e., the number of parameters of the ANN), and improve its computational efficiency. The optimized algorithm was then integrated with an augmented media player developed by the team leading to an initial prototype for AptStream. Depending on the network and algorithm configurations and parameters the benefits of using the proposed solution can vary. Results suggest that AptStream is especially useful when the uplink and downlink bandwidths of the viewers are constrained. In addition, to help with the overall satisfaction of the viewers with the service, AptStream allows the providers/viewers to limit the bandwidth usage of the service without tangible performance degradation. In this case, when implemented widely, AptStream is expected to help with overall reductions in transmissions in the entire network leading to additional direct and indirect cost and energy reductions as well as overall network improvements. 

In typical scenarios AptStream can achieve approximately 60%-90+% reduction in server (i.e., CDN or the Cloud) downloads leading to approximately 2x -- 4x cost reductions. This technology, when widely adopted, can lead to multiple potential broader impacts, for example, on reducing the energy consumption of the underlying infrastructures, facilitating remote education, and empowering smaller businesses in the streaming industry.
